description: A process where the model adjusts its operation based on received data autonomously.
The ability of an AI agent to function independently by making decisions and taking actions without human intervention or other systems' involvement.
A statistical time series model that assumes current observation values depend on previous observations from the same sequence.
Standardized method of communication between agents.

Modeling artifacts may include: training code, execution code, dataset used for training, trained model (weights/coefficients and topology), reports on quality of AI/ML model training, validation pass reports, etc.

Set of documents defining fundamental rules, norms, requirements for architecture, architectural design methodologies, as well as requirements for tools monitoring compliance of architectural artifacts with standards.
Specific case of reactive AI-agent activated upon user request aimed at providing answers or performing simple actions. Differs from full-scale agent due to lack of proactivity, planning, reflection.
Process involving interaction with internal and external bank clients. The main outcomes of business processes are services provided to customers.
Advanced artificial intelligence system based on neural networks trained on vast amounts of textual data capable of processing, understanding, and generating text similar to humans.
Specialized type of database optimized for storing and processing multidimensional vector data (embeddings).
Parameters and variables of the algorithm according to which the model operates. They represent a modeling artifact.
Exchange of information among agents to coordinate actions towards achieving common objectives.
Class of AI models that generate new content based on training data mimicking human creativity across various forms.
Organized collection of data intended for analysis, research, and use in different computational tasks (such as fine-tuning LLMs).
Confidence in another agent's reliability and competence based on past interaction experience.
Process of adapting pretrained model to solve specific problems or operate within certain scenarios.
Collection of facts, events, beliefs, and organized rules extracted from training datasets, provided by users during interactions with the model, and also generated by the model itself.
